title: Malmsbury Youth Justice Centre locked down after assaults
text:
Victoria's prison staff are being assaulted by violent teenagers at a rate of almost one per day. Teenagers at the Parkville Youth Justice Centre have reportedly launched more than 200 assaults on staff in just eight months. Violent incidents have become the biggest source of employee injury at Parkville.

A Victorian youth justice facility has been locked down since this morning over staff fears following a series of assaults.

Staff at the Malmsbury Youth Justice Centre, 95km northwest of Melbourne, locked youth offenders inside their cells and in their units while they met with management from 11.30am.

WorkSafe was called in and representatives are also meeting with staff, according to Julian Kennelly from the Community and Public Sector Union.

“Staff are still on site, it is a cease-work,” he told news.com.au. “Staff had a morning meeting and were asked if they felt safe and they thought it was unsafe.”

He said staff were negotiating for more emergency response personnel.

It follows two attacks on prison staff at the facility on Wednesday and Thursday.

Last year, a female staff member at Malmsbury was “scalped” by a teenage offender who swing a guitar at her head with such force it left a 12cm-wide wound on her hairline.

She didn’t see the guitar coming and was knocked out cold before she hit the ground, staff members say. She has not returned to work.

WARNING: GRAPHIC IMAGE BELOW

Victoria’s Opposition Leader Michael O’Brien said Malmsbury was “a disaster area” and that Premier Daniel Andrews had “lost control of the youth justice system”.

“The government needs to urgently step in, make sure the staff are safe, make sure these young offenders are not allowed to continue with this sort of behaviour,” he said.

News.com.au last month reported on Victoria’s other out-of-control youth justice centre at Parkville on Melbourne’s fringe.

Staff members who spoke on condition of anonymity said they were worried there would be a death at the Parkville Youth Justice Precinct if more staff weren’t called in to help.

“In 48 hours, we’ve had five staff assaults,” one staff member said. “Three were physically injured. One was spat at in the face. One had a missile thrown at him.”

A source claims that of 53 “frontline” staff hired during an induction in April, only four remain in the job. The source also claims there are more than 125 staff receiving WorkCover right now. A Corrections Victoria spokesman would not be drawn on these figures and declined to answer questions about why staff turnover was so high.

“You get more stacking shelves at Coles,” a staff member said.

“They’re coming in at $22 an hour. They think they’re going to be able to do actual youth work and change the world. They don’t get the chance.”

Another staff member said 260 staff had been assaulted between July 2018 and June 2019.

“I’m very surprised there hasn’t been a fatality,” he said.

News.com.au has approached the Department of Justice and Community Safety for comment.
description: A Victorian youth justice facility has been locked down since this morning over staff fears following a series of assaults.
